window_box.page.bouquet0: Bundle up to 3 $(thing)small flowers$(0) into a decorative $(item)Bouquet$(0)!$(p)To insert flowers, right-click the bouquet onto them, or right-click them onto the bouquet. The flowers can be retrieved by right-clicking the bouquet or right-clicking it onto an empty slot.
window_box.page.state_changer_rod0: The $(item)Rod of the Acropolis$(0) allows you, for a small amount of $(thing)Mana$(0), to force certain building blocks to bend in unnatural ways.$(p)$(item)Stairs$(0) can be forced into corner stairs; and $(item)Fences$(0), $(item)Panes$(0), and $(item)Walls$(0) can have their connections adjusted. Blocks may revert to a natural state if updated.
window_box.page.state_changer_rod1: I Can't Believe It's Not Debug Stick!
window_box.page.grass_rod0: The $(item)Rod of the Grasslands$(0) is a simple variant to the $(l:tools/dirt_rod)$(item)Rod of the Lands$(0)$(/l), placing normal $(item)Grass Blocks$(0) instead of $(item)Dirt$(0), for a marginally higher price.$(p)For the same $(thing)Mana$(0) cost, it can supply a $(l:tools/exchange_rod)$(item)Rod of the Shifting Crust$(0)$(/l), or be used by a $(l:devices/avatar)$(item)Livingwood Avatar$(0)$(/l).
window_box.page.grass_rod1: Of splendour in the grass, of glory in the flower
window_box.page.snapdresson0: It can be a hassle to manually swap between sets of $(thing)Trinkets$(0) for different occasions. The $(item)Snapdresson$(0) will remember what $(thing)Trinkets$(0) you're wearing, and when right-clicked will dress you in that loadout, using held items or the contents of a $(l:baubles/bauble_box)$(item)Trinket Case$() or $(item)Shulker Box$(0). It does not consume $(thing)Mana$(0).$(p)You can also give your loadout a label by naming the flower!
window_box.page.candysnuft0: The $(item)Candysnuft$(0) is a generating flower that creates $(thing)Mana$(0) when nearby $(item)candles$(0) are extinguished, $(thing)consuming$(0) a $(item)candle$(0) from the block in the process.$(p)Blocks with 4 $(item)candles$(0) are too much for the $(item)Candysnuft$(0) to take on, and will be ignored.
window_box.page.candysnuft1: Feeding the $(item)Candysnuft$(0) candles from a small number of repeated spots will quickly yield $(thing)diminishing returns.$()$(p)Automation of the $(item)Candysnuft$(0) will require careful manipulation of the $(l:functional_flowers/rannuncarpus)$(item)Rannuncarpus$(). The $(item)candles$(0) can be automatically lit with a $(thing)dispensed$(0) $(item)Flint and Steel$(0), and extinguished with a $(thing)dispensed$(0) $(item)Water Bucket$(0) or $(item)Splash Water Bottle$(0).
block.window_box.queen_anelace.reference: My treasure? Why, it's right where I left it!
window_box.page.queen_anelace0: The $(item)Queen Anelace$(0) is known for its extensive roots, which spread down to the first $(item)Grass Block$(0) up to 8 blocks below, then out through a 9x9 square of $(item)Grass Blocks$(0).$(p)As a defensive adaptation, it concentrates all its $(thing)Mana$(0) in one randomized spot. Pushing or otherwise breaking this block will release the Mana into the flower, and make it choose another spot.
window_box.page.queen_anelace1: Fortunately, there is a way to pinpoint the $(item)Queen Anelace$(0)'s secret spot: each side of the flower emits a redstone signal strength equal to the distance in that direction to the block.$(p)Unfortunately, if you make a mistake and break any other block in that square, it will $(o)cost$() $(thing)Mana$(0) instead, which must be paid back before it can generate more.$(p)If there's no $(item)Grass Block$(0) at its target, it'll wait until there is.
window_box.page.queen_anelace2: $(o)And X never, ever marks the spot$()
window_box.page.groundberry0: The $(item)Groundberry$(0) uses Mana to bury summoned fragments of the past inside any $(item)Sand$(0) and $(item)Gravel$(0) below it. The $(item)Suspicious Sand/Gravel$(0) can then be carefully excavated using an archaeologist's $(item)Brush$(0).$(p)You might even find a unique $(item)Music disc$(0), Armor $(item)Trim Patterns$(0), $(item)Pottery Sherds$(0), or a rare $(item)Sniffer Egg$(0).
death.attack.window_box.groundberry: %1$s was poked to death by a Groundberry bush
death.attack.window_box.groundberry.play: %1$s was poked to death by a Groundberry bush while trying to escape %2$s
window_box.page.oxidaisel0: A cousin of the $(l:basics/pure_daisy)$(item)Pure Daisy$(), the $(item)Oxidaisel$(0) will cause nearby $(item)Copper$(0) blocks to rapidly $(thing)oxidize$().$(p)$(item)Copper$(0) oxidizes from up to 2 blocks away, and does so slower if adjacent to other $(item)Copper$(0) blocks.$(p)Oxidization can be removed from a $(item)Copper$(0) block using an $(item)Axe$(0), or prevented by $(thing)waxing$(0) with $(item)Honeycomb$(0).
window_box.page.oxidaisel1: $(o)Can I get a, uhh, Lightly Weathered Cut Copper Stairs?$()
block.window_box.glory_incarnata.referen: Don't call them the Z word
window_box.page.glory_incarnata0: The tendrils of the $(item)Glory Incarnata$(0) reach beyond the veil of life and death to feed.$(p)With a trickle of $(thing)Mana$(0), it creates an aura of life which prevents certain creatures from $(thing)zombifying$(0), and for a burst of $(thing)Mana$(0) can reverse the $(thing)zombification$(0) outright.
block.window_box.witch_pupil.reference: By the plucking of my plums
window_box.page.witch_pupil0: The $(item)Witch's Pupil$(0) is named for its eerie $(item)Eye Berries$(0); pluck one and when eaten, your vision will be drawn into the plant, able to view out from its many eyes from anywhere in the world.$(p)Each eye plucked from the plant is one you can no longer see through, so be careful not to take them all!
item.window_box.eye_berries.insufficient: Witch's Pupil is out of Mana!
window_box.page.dispelagonium0: The pitchers of the $(item)Dispelagonium$(0) have evolved to drain energy from collected potion fluid.$(p)With a supply of $(thing)Mana$(0), it can extend its feeding to a field around it; splash a potion on it, and it will drain that potion's effects from entities in range, until it finishes consuming the potion.
window_box.page.dispelagonium1: $(o)I'd really love to, chug potions with you$()
block.window_box.topsy_tulip.reference: Floating in the most peculiar way
window_box.page.topsy_tulip0: Ever wanted to be on top of the world? The $(item)Topsy Tulip$(0) can be planted on any side of a block, and creates a field of altered $(thing)gravity$(0) allowing you to walk on walls in a 9x9 plane. $(thing)Mana$(0) is drained for each entity affected. Jump to exit the field!
window_box.page.sapling.facing: The portal will grow facing the nearest player.
window_box.page.chthonic_yew0: The $(thing)Chthonic Yew$(0) tree is said to be a gateway to the underworld. When grown, its trunk forms a hollow containing a portal to the $(thing)Nether$(0). It requires a 2x2 of saplings with 4 blocks of vertical space above them. Its wood is a deep black.
window_box.page.alfthorne0: The legends of the $(thing)Elves$(0) describe a huge $(thing)Alfthorne$(0) tree which once connected our plane to $(thing)Alfheim$(0). While it won't break the seal against travel, growing one could be an alternative to $(l:alfhomancy/intro)other rituals$().$(br)It requires 24 blocks of vertical space above, but won't grow naturally: like the $(l:alfhomancy/intro)artifical portal$(), it requires a large Mana infusion via two $(item)Natura Pylons$(0). Its wood is a vibrant green.
window_box.page.alfthorne1: $(o)For there is nothing lost, that may be found, if sought.$()
